#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk sudo
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: sudo bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The sudo packages contain the sudo utility which allows system administrators to provide certain users with the permission to execute privileged commands, which are used for system management purposes, without having to log in as root. This update fixes the following bugs: Previously, the sudo utility did not correctly handle the "sudo -ll" command when the System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) was used to obtain available sudo entries. Consequently, running "sudo -ll" returned incomplete results, as it did not list the rule names of sudo entries. A patch has been applied to fix this bug, and "sudo -ll" now lists the rule names as expected when SSSD is used. (BZ#1088464) When a sudo rule contained the +netgroup variable in the sudoUser attribute, the system ignored the rest of the sudo rule under certain circumstances. Consequently, executing the "sudo -l" command did not show the complete list of rules configured for the specified user. With this update, the problem has been fixed, and running "sudo -l" now shows the complete list of rules even when a sudo rule contains the +netgroup variable. (BZ#1088825) Previously, sudo did not correctly handle the situation when the group specification in the /etc/sudoers file contained escape characters on systems integrated with the Active Directory (AD) service. As a consequence, specifying a custom password prompt for a group containing escape characters did not work, as sudo displayed the default password prompt when a member of that group used sudo. A patch has been applied to fix this bug, and setting a custom password prompt now works as expected even if the group specification contains escape characters. (BZ#1092499) The pam_faillock module did not acknowledge attempts to terminate sudo login with the Ctrl+C shortcut after the password prompt appeared. As a consequence, sudo continued trying to log in and eventually locked the user out. The problem has been fixed, and even though an attempt terminated with Ctrl+C still counts as one failed attempt to log in, sudo no longer locks the user out. (BZ#1093099) Previously, sudo did not correctly handle setting the NIS domain name value as "(none)", as it considered the "(none)" text string a valid domain name. Consequently, the getdomainname() function returned "(none)" as the NIS domain name instead of recognizing that no domain name was set. The source code has been updated to fix this problem, and sudo now handles the described situation correctly. (BZ#1096813) Previously, sudo did not correctly handle the situation when the /etc/nsswitch.conf file contained the "sudoers: files sss sss" entry. As a consequence, the duplicate "sss" entry caused sudo to become unresponsive after issuing a command. With this update, the problem has been fixed, and sudo no longer hangs when the configuration file contains "sudoers: files sss sss". (BZ#1147497) Prior to this update, sudo did not respond correctly to the root user's request to list the privileges for a specified user when SSSD was used. As a consequence, running the "sudo -l -U" command for a normal user as root returned incomplete results, while running the same command as the normal user worked as expected. The source code has been updated to fix this problem, and executing "sudo -l -U" as root now returns correct results. (BZ#1147557) The Clang static analyzer found a number of defects in the sudo packages. A patch has been applied to fix these problems. (BZ#1147616) In addition, this update adds the following enhancement: With this update, sudo has been modified to accept the ipa_hostname value from the /etc/sssd/sssd.conf file when matching netgroups. (BZ#1084488) Users of sudo are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add this enhancement. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
